oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Safe conduct pass issued by the Republic of Vietnam
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color two-sided pass promising safe conduct to the holder of the pass by all Vietnamese government agencies and allied military forces. Reverse bears the signature of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky and has a photograph of a South Vietnamese Soldier standing next to a Viet-Cong defector.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Propaganda

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Military passes; Safe-conducts; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. American involvement later came to dominate this pacification program. An estimated 160,000 defections occurred. The airdrop leaflet was the most commonly used item of inducement, but leaflets were also distributed by hand.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
Passport
Safe-conduct pass to honored by all Vietnamese government agencies and allied forces
By carrying this passport and
coordinating with the National
government you will:
• Be kindly received
• Have safety ensured
• Be suitably treated
This Passport is valid with all military organizations of the Republic OF Vietnam and its allies (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)
